column4: in your case you may have a kernel with name linux-image-2.6.35-2.6.35 - correct?
or uname -r
which is linux-image-2.6.35.13-2.6.35
can i rename the new kernel?:D
usually the kernel images are located in /boot - and they are not deleted - just because a new kernel is installed
One has to manually remove / delete them and update grub
u planning to build a kernel?
i finished: fakeroot make-kpkg --initrd --append-to-version=-some-string-here kernel-image kernel-headers
did you type anything for "some-string-here" ???
yes i wrote: --append-to-version=2.6.35
here's the deal ---append-to-version is used to put custom name e.g. "my-custom-kernel"
what should i do now?
so when you compile your kernel - the kernel name will be linux-image-2.6.35-my-custom-kernel
yes: linux-headers-2.6.35.132.6.35 ;(
what is the output of      uname -a
2.6.35-27-generic
- you are good to go - here is why ---- your current kernal is linux-image-2.6.35-27-generic - which is different from the kernel you just compiled
yes - before installing you can ----- after installing - you need to update grub (bootloader) to have the right name of the kernel file and location
can u help me?:D
go to the directory where you have the kernel
and how to install it now?
how long does it take to install the kernel approx?
depends on your system - 1 min - 5 min
/usr/share/doc --- is  your documentation folder
